Risk Management Plant (RMP) Executive Summary  5-year resubmission
MGC Pure Chemical America, Inc (MGC) is required to develop a RMP for the Ammonium Hydroxide Purification Plant located in Killeen, Texas hereafter referred to as the Ammonium Hydroxide process.
As required by 40 CFR 68.155, MGC developed this RMP Executive Summary for the Ammonium Hydroxide process.
1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Release Policies
MGCs policy is to respond to emergencies and minimize employee exposure and potential injury. This is done through training of onsite personnel and contractors working on the site, the use of various safeguards to control hazards associated with potentially hazardous work, and the use of alarms during operations to detect anomalies in process operations.
2.	Facility and Regulated Substances
MGC has one regulated substance, anhydrous ammonia, at the Mesa facility. The facility uses anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide to create ultra-pure ammonium hydroxide. The facility is subject to the Program Level 3 RMP requirements. [The OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation also applies to the facility because the anhydrous ammonia onsite exceeds the PSM limit of 10,000 pounds.]
The Covered Process includes the following:  anhydrous ammonia storage tank and piping to Ammonia Hydroxide Purification Plant.
	Bulk liquid ammonia unloading station
	Bulk ammonia storage 
	Ammonia gas scrubber 
	Ammonia drain evaporator offloading 
	Equipment in ammonia service 
The following sections briefly describe the elements of the MGC release prevention program that are in place at its stationary source. 
3.	Release Prevention Program at Killeen Plant 
a.	Process Safety Information (PSI)
MGC maintains PSI records onsite and at a third-party database APSM that describe chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the regulated substance and Covered Process.
b.	Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios
Informati

on on the worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios is maintained in Section 2 of the facility RMP  Hazard Assessment: Off-Site Consequence Analysis.

c.	Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA)
MGC conducted PHA studies (PHAs) to identify hazards associated with its Covered Process and review if appropriate controls were in place. The methodology used to carry out these analyses was the hazard and operability (HAZOP) technique. The PHAs were undertaken by teams of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations. The PHAs were revalidated at least every five years. Findings and recommendations related to the PHAs were addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA for the Covered Process was completed on September 20-21, 2022. 
d. Operating Procedures
MGC maintains written operating procedures to safely conduct activities in the Covered Process. These procedures address various modes of operation, such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in these procedures.
e.	Training 
MPCA has a training program for employees tasked with operational processes and procedures. Refresher training is provided at least once every three years for employees that work with the Covered Process. MGC maintains records of the training that has been provided to employees.
f.	Mechanical Integrity
MGC has a preventive maintenance program for the equipment in the Covered Process. MGC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Covered Process equipment examined by these checks includes, among others: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  
Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance p

ractices. MGC has established and implemented written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment. Equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 
g.	Management Of Change (MOC)
MGC has a written MOC process for the Covered Process to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, personnel, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or other employees whose tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to address the modifications. 
h.	Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
MGC has a PSSR program for the Covered Process. The facility performs Pre-Startup Safety Reviews related to new processes and modifications of the Covered Process. The reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. A completed PSSR is required prior to introducing hazardous materials to the process.
i.	Compliance Audits
MGC conducts RMP compliance audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP regulation are being implemented. The last RMP compliance audit for the facility was completed in April 2022.
j.	Incident Investigation
MGC investigates incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result, in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situations leading to each incident, as well as corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. Incident Investigation reports related to the Covered Process are retained for a minimum of five years. 
k.	Employee Participation 
MGC has developed a written employee participation plan. MGC employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend measures for improvement.  
l.	Contractors 
Prior to selecting a contractor, MPCA

completes an evaluation of the safety performance of the contractor. MGC trains contract employees on potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the Covered Process. Contractors are also informed of the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. 
4.	Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidents or releases of anhydrous ammonia within the 5-year tracking period that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
5.	Emergency Response Program

MGC complies with applicable federal, state, and local regulations related to emergency response plans. This facility has an emergency action plan that provides instructions to employees on how to respond to various emergencies, including releases of anhydrous ammonia from the Covered Process. Employees and contractors are also informed of hazards in the workplace. Employees who work with potentially hazardous substances receive training that includes emergency procedures.
MGC coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) so that the LEPC is aware of the Covered Process, the anhydrous ammonia, and the emergency procedures proposed in the MGC Emergency Action Plan. MGC has provided a copy of the Emergency Response Plan to the following local agencies: 
	Killeen Fire Station No. 3
	Killeen Police Department 

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility does not have planned changes at this moment. The facility will continue practicing safety practices for regulated substances.
